metadata.name: Buizen #129
metadata.description:
"Buizen" is a generative art algorithm that creates interesting and somewhat chaotic compositions of tube-like shapes. The word "Buizen" is Dutch for "tubes". It was born out of exploring the fields of (arc) tangent math.

The algorithm starts with filling a canvas full of circles. It then pairs up the circles, either randomly or by selecting those that are close or on the same angle. The two circles are then connected to each other as one shape using arc tangent math. The addition of hatching for shading and a hollow opening on one end creates an illusion of depth, resulting in shapes that resemble tubes.

Variations in the final output are driven by differences in creating circle pairs, as well as factors such as circle packing density, circle sizes, color palette, and curvature of the tubes.

metadata.name: Mistakes #27
metadata.description:
Have you ever found your path by accidentally making a mistake?
This was what happened to me... while exploring some possibilities in coding I made a mistake, and that made me explore on that direction and creating this project!

"Mistakes" project represents how chaotic our lives can be and how many decisions we need to make in our path. All the choices are possible. All the choices are valid. But still we need to decide where to go.

Don't ever be afraid to try and make mistakes. They can bring you to such wonderful places!

metadata.name: Solstice #59
metadata.description:
Each output is generated by layering Blender renders.

'Solstice' is a colorful, striking design created with a vintage color palette.

This results in an image with a warm, summer feel.

In live mode:
Click/tap the image to make a "Download image" button appear. Click this button to download a 1500x2000px PNG.

metadata.name: Streaming #35
metadata.description:
Streaming is an exploration of curl noise and rounding errors, using fx(params) to shape the piece.

My own method for producing pieces of interest is to randomise all parameters, then lock favourable aspects and experiment with altering one or two parameters. If the piece is too dark, reduce the render length or increase the stroke weight. If the piece seems too light, alter the volatility of the noise, or slow it down with increased friction. Each parameter can, of course, be explained in great detail, but in reality the best way to work with the piece is to play.

The random numbers for the piece are generated using the minter's address, meaning that what you see as a live preview will be the exact mint received.

Made using Hydra (https://hydra.ojack.xyz/)

Rangga Purnama Aji, 2022

The visual representation shows liquid-like textures with various colors that are placed together and create a mixed-imposed composition.

metadata.name: The Paradox of Choice #385
metadata.description:
### OVERVIEW ###
This project revisits some of the foundational ideas in my previous work "Above (The Infinite)" and makes them available in a parameterized form for your exploration.

This project both rewards and requires exploration. I intentionally left the parameter space very broad so that edge case configurations would be possible. In practice this means that additional curation beyond the initial random parameters will very likely be required, in a way that mimics my day to day experience as a generative artist.

Thanks to Karsten Schmidt for his excellent thi.ng libraries (https://thi.ng/), which form the technical foundation upon which this work was built.

### CONTROLS ###
e - Save the current frame as a PNG
space - Pause/Resume animation

### PARAMETERS ###
NOTE: Some combinations of parameters will cause flashing/strobing, which is why I have attached the "Epileptic Seizure" label to the project.

* Color Palette: The color palette to apply to the output.
* Merge Technique: The method used to combine the different patterns.
* Patterns: The various patterns that can be combined to form the overall resulting tiled pattern.
* Pattern Scales: The scales used to combine patterns. Higher scale values provide more visible pattern repetition.
* Deformers: An optional additional spatial deformation of a pattern.
* Deformer Scales: The scale of the deformation itself. Lower values use less of the deformation space, while higher values include more.
* Detail: Acts as a filter on the visual complexity of the overall tiled pattern. Lower values will reduce visual complexity, while higher values will increase it.
* Rotation Rate/Scroll Rates: How fast should the image rotate or scroll. Note: adjusting these parameters may result in visuals that trigger motion sickness.
* Zoom: Lower values zoom in, higher values zoom out.
* Round Scales Up?: When checked the pattern scales are rounded up to the nearest integer.
* Animate?: Should some parameters be adjusted with the passing of time?
* Low Res?: When checked, force device pixel density to 1, which reduces strain on the GPU, but may result in graphical artifacts. I usually keep this unchecked unless I want to lighten the load on the GPU.
* Anti-alias?: When checked each pixel will be sampled multiple times to attempt to smooth out possible aliasing. This will put more load on the GPU, and will typically be slower. Can be useful when "Low Res?" is enabled.

### HOWTO ###
Here's how I find interesting things.

First, I lock all of the parameters below "Pattern 3" at their default values. I will also usually lock both Deformers to "Empty", as they can sometimes hide interesting patterns while exploring, and then I experiment with enabling one or both once I have found something interesting.

You can also explore the options individually (to a certain degree) by setting other patterns to "Empty". This can make how patterns affect one another more obvious when you set them.

At this point I'll randomize the parameters, and then do one of the following:

- If I see something that's extremely noisy/detailed, I'll turn down the "Detail" level, which can sometimes smooth things out.

- If a tiling is very tight, I'll lower the "Zoom" to see more of the pattern, or the reverse if I want to see more overview.

- If there's still a lot of aliasing/noise in the image, sometimes enabling anti-aliasing will help, but that will affect performance. I usually try to adjust the Scale/Detail/Zoom before resorting to anti-aliasing.

- Interesting patterns are formed by the scale factors controlling how pattern overlap happens. Sometimes enabling "Round Scales Up?" will introduce some appealing visual symmetry.

- Enable one or both of the deformers to see what impact they have on the pattern.

Finally, once I've found a pattern that's interesting, I may enable scrolling or rotation. Note that enabling additional movement can increase graphical aliasing, so anti-aliasing may be required depending on the pattern.

I hope you enjoy the exploration process!

- Jeff Palmer

metadata.name: Multicolored Pixelated Field #18
metadata.description:
"The pixelated field radiates multicolored textures while relentlessly changing motions. A fantasy, imagination, and a place where ever-changing dream might reside within."

/////INTERACTIVITY/////
Do all the instructions below after opening the live mode.

1. To capture the screen, press the "c" button on your computer keyboard.

2. To save a 5-second .GIF from your iteration, press the "s" button on your computer keyboard. Please be patient while waiting for the piece to save and render its frames.

3. To adjust the piece resolution, you need to set your browser first and then reload the browser every time you want to capture the screen or save the rendered .GIF file.
///////////////////////

Created using Hydra and p5.js

Rangga Purnama Aji, 2022
https://linktr.ee/ranggapuraji

metadata.name: Fragment #137
metadata.description:
▪️ 28 Variables
▪️ [left mouse button] hold to rotate
▪️ [mouse wheel] to zoom in and out
▪️ [right mouse button] to reset the view
▪️ [r] to toggle auto rotation [on by default]
▪️ [i] to toggle inverted colours
▪️ [s] to open the image capture popup on the top right [Live only capture]
▪️▪️ Maximum recommended width and height is 4096px [Higher resolutions might fail]
▪️ The piece does not stretch but instead it adjusts to the screen size and ratio
▪️ Designed to have a strong visual impact so might not be suitable for mobile
▪️ Created as a free gift to holders of any of my projects on fxhash as of 03.08.2022

metadata.name: FxPlanet #333
metadata.description:
🟢〰Storyline〰🟢

Once upon a time, a God had a little daughter. The daughter liked to explore the planets on his father's cosmos. Suddenly the daughter got sick and died like a collapsing star. God gets alone, angry, depressed and finally mad. He turned all the universe to ash and mixed the ash of her daughter's soul with it to make her alive, But he failed. In the end, he decided to destroy himself to make a New cosmos of all generative planets from ash of himself and his daughter's soul to one more time in the eternity they can be with each other in a heart of a planet. If you listen carefully to the planets, you may hear them calling each other.

⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛

🔴〰Rarity〰🔴

This collection is a 3D generative interactive artwork (Made with Unity Game Engine) that contains of 9999+1 planets (1 shared source of light and 9999 pieces of souls) from billions of variation. You can see more random variations from fxhash page.
◼ The beauty and complexity of the Planet's surface is important, But what is going on inside?
Each planet has three grades of volume (High, Medium, Low) that show you what resources exist on the planets (Common, Rare, Legendary).
Some resources are so valuable and infrequent.
◼ For Example: It's possible to get Oxygen (Legendary Resource) on Low volume slot, but it's infrequent if you get it on High volume slot.
◼ Checkout Material rarity list on webpage.

📎 Webpage address: HashProtocol.tez.page

⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛

🔵〰Social〰🔵

◼ Participant in events or get achievements to win some prizes.
So it's significant to see you on the discord server. Checkout rarity table, achievements rewards, … on the webpage.
📎 Webpage address: HashProtocol.tez.page

⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛

🟠〰Interact〰🟠

◼ You can rotate around of planets by “WASD” keys on the keyboard or arrow keys.
◼ Zoom In by “E” key and Zoom Out by “Q”.
◼ Full HD texture by Key “1”.
◼ 4k texture by Key “2”.
◼ 8k texture by Key “3”.
